title: IDOR when editing email leads to Account Takeover on Atavist
content:
Summary:
Hi team,
I created an account on Atavist and checked my settings page.
I can change my email at https://magazine.atavist.com/cms/reader/account with this request :
<image_0>
And as you can see, there is a id parameter on request data. It's our user ID, and it's vulnerable for IDOR. So we can change any user's email address.
Also user IDs are sequential so an attacker can change all accounts' email.
Steps To Reproduce:
1.Go to https://magazine.atavist.com/login and Login to your account
Go to https://magazine.atavist.com/cms/reader/account and open your proxy program
Change the email and click Save
In request, change the ID to your test account's ID
Forward the request
Now you can reset victim's password via https://magazine.atavist.com/forgot
Impact
Account Takeover without user interaction
Thanks,
Bugra
steps: Go to https://magazine.atavist.com/login and log in to your account.
Navigate to https://magazine.atavist.com/cms/reader/account and open your proxy program.
Change the email and click Save.
In the request, modify the 'id' parameter to another user's ID (sequential IDs make this easy).
Forward the request to change the victim's email.
Use the password reset feature at https://magazine.atavist.com/forgot to take over the victim's account.
vuln_description: The vulnerability is an Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in the email change functionality, allowing an attacker to modify any user's email address by manipulating the 'id' parameter in the request. Since user IDs are sequential, this can lead to mass account takeovers.
reason: The attack is straightforward, involving only the manipulation of a single parameter in a predictable request. No complex interactions or novel logic are required, and the sequential nature of IDs makes enumeration trivial.

authnz_metadata.reason: The vulnerability involves an IDOR where the user ID in the request can be manipulated to change another user's email address. This fits the methodology's test case e) where substituting the resource_id (user ID) with another user's ID and executing the action with an existing user session would reveal the vulnerability.
